awd_titl_txt: REU Site: An Integrated Diversity Undergraduate Research Experience in Functional Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent advances in nanomaterials and device physics have brought about new frontiers in undergraduate education and training. To address these scientific challenges and to significantly broaden outreach to underrepresented minority and women's groups in science and engineering, the University of California-Los Angeles (UCLA) will conduct a REU Site program, An Integrated Diversity Undergraduate Research Experience in Functional NanoMaterials (FNM) in partnership with the Center for Function Accelerated nanoMaterial Engineering (FAME) at UCLA. FAME is a long-standing effective industry-academia partnership, with world-leading research and competencies in unconventional materials and new correlated physics for next-generation device technologies. The REU research projects will focus on world-class unconventional materials and device physics for next-generation um and nm-scale electronics and optoelectronics. 
  
UCLA will host 10 REU students over a 10-week summer program where they will participate in interdisciplinary research projects on functional nanomaterials.  Mentoring and cohesive cohort-wide activities will be central tenets to this REU. FNM will implement weekly faculty-student updates and discussions, weekly REU site-wide professional development and cross-training workshops, in addition to external periodic surveys with feedback action items, and a cumulative symposium for the REU scholars.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Our REU Site on An Integrated Diversity Undergraduate Research Experience in Functional Nanomaterials provided summer research training experiences for 34 leading undergraduate scholars in community colleges, UCLA and other universities, with more than 75% students of minority and women representation. The majority (more than ~ 55%) are from community colleges. The topical focus spans from nanomaterials to spectroscopy, laser physics to signal processing.

We trained undergraduate students from more than 10 community colleges, and are happy to report many of them have gone on to universities, transferring to UCLA for example, and are pursuing STEM career pathways. The selectivity for the REU Site scholar positions is about 20% or less, where typically our site has about 50 to 60 students applying each year.

Our site coordinator is able to provide well-prepared scaffolding before each summer, on-boarding each cohort to our UCLA in-person research experience. The eight-week summer research program includes matching with REU faculty and a graduate student mentor for each undergraduate student. The summer experience cumulates with a Science Poster Day on-campus, along with a best poster award. The first summer of the REU Site was held in 2018, subsequently in 2019. In 2020, the pandemic paused the entire university’s non-essential on-campus visitors. We restarted in 2021 with a remote-only experience allowed by most universities, and completed in 2022 summer with an in-person experience finally for the students’ benefit. In each year, we learnt from the best practices of the undergraduate research training and improved on each year’s delivery to the undergraduate students.
